name: Total Charitable Giving
description: Charitable giving can occur through many different avenues for generosity. Here, we use one measure of aggregate charitable giving, which includes contributions from individuals, corporations, bequests, and foundations.

measures.name: Total charitable contributions
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulations of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

name: Individual giving
description: Individuals, as opposed to institutions, have long represented the largest source of charitable giving in the United States. Giving by the ultra-wealthy continues to represent a disproportionately large share of giving by individuals.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Share of charitable contributions made by ultra-wealthy individuals
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated by WealthX’s Philanthropic Giving Model, which analyzes the annual philanthropic donations made by ultra-wealthy individuals in each market (those with a net worth of more than $30 million). WealthX then uses its proprietary Wealth and Investable Assets Model to estimate total philanthropic giving (as a proportion of total wealth) in each region. These figures exclude giving by corporations as well as businesses owned by the ultra-wealthy.

measures.name: Share of charitable donations lessthan $5,001
measures.notes: Estimates are based on GivingTuesday’s Growth in Giving dataset, which is a longitudinal database of donation transactions by individuals in the US aggregated from many sources (including customer relationship management databases and other giving platforms). Transactions included in this database are limited to those made to 501(c)3s with no more than $25M in contributions and with data from three consecutive years.

name: Noncash Charitable Contributions
description: Not all giving comes in the form of cash. Many organizations accept non-cash assets, including publicly traded securities (stocks, bonds and mutual funds) and non-publicly traded assets (private stock, restricted stock, and limited partnership interests). These contributions can be itemized on taxpayers’ yearly tax returns.

measures.name: Total annual value of noncash charitable contributions

sources.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report

measures.notes: Noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions are calculated by the IRS Statistics of Income Division, aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns.

measures.name: Share of non-cash assets among all itemized charitable contributions

sources.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report

measures.notes: Noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions are calculated by the IRS Statistics of Income Division, aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns.

name: Volunteering
description: Volunteering is a core component of how individuals express generosity. Much of the data on volunteering registers how individuals help tax-exempt nonprofit institutions, but volunteers can also assist informal organizations and association.

measures.name: Share of Americans who volunteer

sources.source: Bureau of Labor Statisticsand Corporation for National and Community Service

measures.notes: Estimates pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002-2015 and recently transitioned to the Corporation for National and Community Service starting in 2017. The count of volunteers only includes persons who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include persons who volunteered in a more informal manner.

measures.name: Total hours volunteered
measures.notes: Estimates pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002-2015 and recently transitioned to the Corporation for National and Community Service (CNCS) starting in 2017. The count of volunteers only includes persons who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include persons who volunteered in a more informal manner.

name: Impact investing
description: Impact investments intentionally seek social and environmental impact as well as financial returns and offer a way beyond charitable giving for individuals and institutions to have an impact.

measures.name: Share of affluent households who participate in impact investing

sources.source: Bank of America/IUPUI Lilly School of Philanthropy

measures.notes: Estimates are based on 2021 nationally representative random sample of 1,626 high-net-worth households and includes in-depth analysis based on age, gender, race, and sexual identity by IUPUI’s Lilly School of Philanthropy. High-net-worth households are defined as households with a net worth of $1M+ and/or have an annual income of $200,000+.

measures.name: Total DAF assets in impact investment pools at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from 153,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Total amount of recoverable grantsby Fidelity Charitable DAFs to charities
measures.notes: Recoverable grants are donations that can be repaid under some circumstances. Estimates are calculated using data from 153,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database. Most recent study conducted January-December 2020.

name: Political giving
description: Traditionally, giving to political campaigns has not been considered a form of charitable giving. But the lines between political and charitable giving are becoming increasingly blurred through giving vehicles such as limited liability companies. Donations to party-focused organizations such as WinRed or ActBlue as well as donations to individual candidates or campaigns comprise political giving. (Gifts to 501(c)4s or political action committees are not included in this summary.)

measures.name: Total donors that gave over $200 to a political campaign
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January-December). Fluctuations in political donations year-to-year are partially attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years vs. off-year elections).

measures.name: Total money contributed to political campaigns from donations over $200
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January-December). Fluctuations in political donations year-to-year are in part attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years vs. off-year elections).

measures.name: Money donated to WinRed
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in June 2019, WinRed allows individuals to donate to Republican candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using WinRed’s platform.

measures.name: Money donated to ActBlue
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in 2004, ActBlue allows individuals to donate to Democratic candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using ActBlue’s platform.

name: Giving by Bequest
description: Charitable bequests, which are tax-deductible gifts through a will or trust, can come in many forms and represent a significant share of total charitable contributions.

measures.name: Total giving by bequest
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions given through bequest
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics

name: Remittance Giving
description: Remittance giving constitutes cross-border, often recurrent person-to-person payments of relatively low value by migrants to their home countries.

measures.name: Remittances sent from US residents abroad
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from Gross Domestic Product data from International Monetary Fund World Economic Outlook annually.

name: Donor-Advised Funds
description: Donor-advised funds (DAFs) are giving accounts established at public charities that allow donors to make a charitable contribution, receive an immediate tax deduction, and recommend grants over time. The public charity maintains legal control over the contributions and works with the donor who can advise on funding recommendations.

measures.name: Total value of contributions made to donor-advised funds
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 976 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Total number of DAFs in the US
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 976 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Share of DAF contributions made as noncash assets at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from about 154,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Total dollars contributed to DAFs at community foundations
measures.notes: Estimates are sourced from a non-representative survey of 84 US community foundations. Study conducted between late 2020 and early 2021.

name: Workplace Giving
description: Americans have long donated to charity through their employers, with contributions often channeled through payroll deductions. The employer would either donate these earmarked directly to a charity like the United Way or through a campaign like the Combined Federal Campaign. But workplace giving has declined in recent decades, with new technology and norms placing more autonomy in individual employees and less in the firms or charitable intermediaries.

measures.name: Total value of donations made through Benevity
measures.notes: Benevity provides software that facilitates workplace giving and is used by many Fortune 500 companies. Estimates use Benevity’s master database which includes activities of more than 650 companies, including clients, users of the software and the community of causes.

measures.name: Aggregate charitable contributions from workplace giving programs
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a 2017 survey conducted by America’s Charites of 1586 employees, representing 18 industry groups (education, financial, government, healthcare, technology, nonprofit, professional services, and consumer products).This figure is the most comprehensive and recent data point to capture the scale of workplace giving.

measures.name: Total dollars pledged by federal employees through the Combined Federal Campaign
measures.notes: The Combined Federal Campaign (CFC) is a federal government workplace giving campaign that allows federal employees and retirees to pledge monetary support to approved charities. Summary figures are released by the Office of Personnel Management and include aggregated pledges to charities by federal employees participating in the CFC campaign.

measures.name: Participation rate of federal employees in the Combined Federal Campaign
measures.notes: The Combined Federal Campaign (CFC) is a federal government workplace giving campaign that allows federal employees and retirees to pledge monetary support to approved charities. Summary figures are released by the Office of Personnel Management and include aggregated pledges to charities by federal employees participating in the CFC campaign.

measures.name: Total corporate giving
measures.notes: Estimates for aggregate total giving are based on the sum of the total investments of all companies participating in the Giving in Number survey, which asks companies to report total contributions on a fiscal year basis (end date for 12 months of data).

name: Online Giving
description: Online giving includes any gift made through the internet, on any device or platform. The development of new electronic payment software, which includes any donations made using a credit or debit card, has enabled online giving and allowed more charitable organizations to accept electronic donations.

measures.name: Share of all donations, excluding grants, made online
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from financial analysis of Blackbaud clients. Latest study conducted from January to December 2020, including 4,964 non-profit organizations. Analysis does not include unfulfilled portion of the pledge gifts or recurring gifts that are processed offline.

measures.name: Percent change in number of online donations
measures.notes: Estimates use anonymized and aggregated Mastercard transaction data to provide an analysis of current and historical donation trends.

measures.name: Percent change in individual donations made through electronic payment
measures.notes: Estimates use anonymized and aggregated Mastercard transaction data to provide an analysis of current and historical donation trends.

name: Point of Sale
description: Charity checkout campaigns offer customers an opportunity to donate during the checkout or payment process, by rounding up, adding to their total, or having the vendor automatically make a contribution on the buyer’s behalf.

measures.name: Money raised by major charity checkout campaigns
measures.notes: Estimates are aggregated self-reported data from 76 fundraising campaigns that have raised at least $1,000,000.

measures.name: Cumulative donations to Lyft’s Round Up and Donate program
measures.notes: Started in 2017, the Round Up and Donate program by Lyft, a rideshare company, allows passengers to donate to a cause of their choice. Estimates provided by Lyft on how much their riders have donated to Lyft’s sponsored charitable organizations since the inception of Round Up and Donate in 2017.

measures.name: Total donated to charities from AmazonSmile
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from aggregated donations made via AmazonSmile, a program where shoppers can buy goods through smile.amazon.com and choose from over one million eligible 501(c)(3) public charitable organizations for Amazon to donate 0.5 percent of eligible purchases.

name: Digital currency
description: With the rise and increasing societal acceptance of digital currencies, such as Bitcoin, more charitable organizations are allowing digital currency donations. In recent years, some donors have made extremely large contributions involving cryptocurrency, though the exact value of the donations have fluctuated dramatically given the high volatility of many digital coins.

measures.name: Charitable contributions in the form of cryptocurrency to Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from 153,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database. Study conducted January-December 2020.

name: Donor participation
description: One of the distinguishing characteristics of charitable giving in the US has long been the large share of Americans who report giving to charitable organizations. But in recent years, research suggests that share has been in steady decline. Whether that decline in the “donor pool” reflects a lessening or a rechanneling of charitable giving is a major question confronting researchers.

measures.name: Share of US households who report donating money to one or more charitable organization in the last year

sources.source: Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy

measures.notes: Data from The Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy’s Philanthropy Panel Study (PPS), which is a module of the University of Michigan’s Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID). The PPS is biennial surveys with data collected in odd years about behaviors in even years (e.g., the 2019 wave of the PPS was collected in 2019 about giving in 2018), with a sample size of 7,000-9,000 per wave. The PPS limits questions about giving to households who gave at least $25. Therefore, individuals or household who donated between $1 and $24 are marked as non-donors in the PPS data.

measures.name: Share of Americans who report donating money to a charitable organization in the last year
measures.notes: Estimates rely on telephone interviews conducted by pollsters with a random sample of more than 1000 adults living in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Respondents are asked separately about donating money/volunteering time to charitable organizations.

measures.name: Percent change in total number of donors from previous year
measures.notes: Estimates of total donors are calculated by the Fundraising Effectiveness Project using anonymized giving transaction data from a variety of donor softwares, such as Bloomerang, DonorPerfect, ETapestry, NeonOne, and Clearview. Surveys conducted each year from 2015 to 2019 and included 10,640 non-profit organizations in 2019.

measures.name: Donor retention rate
measures.notes: Estimates of total donors are calculated by the Fundraising Effectiveness Project using anonymized giving transaction data from a variety of donor softwares, such as Bloomerang, DonorPerfect, ETapestry, NeonOne, and Clearview. Donor retention rate represents the percent of donors that made repeat gifts to participating nonprofits from the previous year. Surveys conducted each year from 2015 to 2019 and included 10,640 non-profit organizations in 2019.

name: Mutual Aid
description: Mutual aid has a long tradition and has been defined in many ways, including “any group, often unincorporated, organized with the intention of meeting the immediate needs of their fellow neighbors”.

measures.name: Number of donations to mutual aid networks through ioby
measures.notes: Estimates are pulled from raw data provided by ioby, a crowdfunding platform. The 2020 estimate only contains data from March-December of the year, so is an incomplete comparison to 2021 but is included above to contextualize change over time. The totals do not include matched contributions made by ioby. The definition of mutual aid comes from Erin Barnes, co-founder and CEO of ioby.

name: Collaborative giving
description: Giving circles are groups that pool their time and money and decide communally where those resources should be donated.

measures.name: Total giving circles in the Global Giving Circle Directory
measures.notes: Estimate pulled from Philanthropy Together’s Global Giving Circle Directory as of October 2021. The Global Giving Circle Directory provides a searchable directory of giving circles created by Philanthropy Together, a global initiative to promote giving circles.

name: Crowdfunding
description: Crowdfunding, which entails a large number of people each donating small amounts of money, has grown in popularity in recent years in large part because of virtual crowdfunding platforms, such as GoFundMe and DonorsChoose, and apps that have simplified monetary transactions.

measures.name: Average crowdfunding gift size
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a 2020 survey of 1,535 US households developed by the Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and fielded using the AmeriSpeak panel by NORC. Weights were applied in the analysis to ensure that the final sample was representative of the general U.S. households.

measures.name: Total money raised from GoFundMe campaigns since 2010
measures.notes: GoFundMe allows individuals to set up crowdfunding campaigns for any purpose. Estimates are sourced from GoFundMe public reports that share estimates of money raised across all campaigns, which aggregate all donations made to crowdfunding campaigns across the platform since it was founded in 2010 (not annual estimates).

measures.name: Share of donations made on GoFundMe under $50
measures.notes: GoFundMe allows individuals to set up crowdfunding campaigns for any purpose. Estimates are sourced from GoFundMe public reports for 2019 and 2020, which aggregate all donations made to crowdfunding campaigns across the platform.

measures.name: Total grants and contributions to DonorsChoose
measures.notes: DonorsChoose allows teachers to set up crowdfunding campaigns for classroom projects. Estimates are drawn from DonorsChoose’s public tax records, isolating the contributions and grants component of their annual total revenue.

name: Giving Days
description: Giving days, which are organized efforts to mobilize large-scale donations, often use hashtags and social media to motivate potential donors. The largest giving day, GivingTuesday, the Tuesday after Thanksgiving, was launched in the US in 2012 and is now hosted in more than 70 countries worldwide.

measures.name: Total dollars donated in the US on GivingTuesday
measures.notes: Estimates are based on GivingTuesday Data Collaborative’s statistical model that estimates online and offline giving.

measures.name: Total US online donations made on GivingTuesday
measures.notes: Estimates are based on GivingTuesday Data Collaborative’s aggregation of transaction data from their network of platform reports each year.
